Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: You learn the basic genetics, including pedigree analysis, Hardy-Weinberg, mutations, development, and allele interactions. It was very comprehensive and well taught.
I definitely learned a lot more about mapping genes, developmental genetics, the various types of mutations that can occur, etc.
Thinking about the history of genetics, genetics itself, what experiments have been done/can be done to further our understanding of it

I learned a ton about different topics related to genetics, from mutation to population genetics to epigenetics to linkage, etc. I improved the way I approach scientific problems, and the course continuously helped me link the material to real-life issues in biology and in the world.
I feel like I really learned a lot in this course, and that I learned it well enough to retain and apply it! We covered genetics on the molecular to population level.

I learned a lot about genetics and genetic analysis from this course. I thought it was a good introduction, and the assessments were fair. I learned a lot about population genetics that I didn't know previously, and, overall, feel like I'm better able to talk about genetics, which I think is one of the most important fields out there!
The course helped me build a comprehensive foundation in genetics, which is much needed for my research
I learned basic statistical analyses for genetics and the fundamentals of genetics.

-chi squared tests
-genetic screens
-fundamentals of inheritance 
-genetic mutagens
Basics of genetics, mutations, population genetics, epigenetics
This is more of a traditional genetics course, and I really enjoyed it.

MCDB 202 is taught as a course in "classical genetics," in the words of Prof. Dellaporta, which entails your typical Mendelian genetics but also population genetics, bioinformatics, etc. as opposed to molecular studies as is encompassed in Molecular Biology, Epigenetics, and The Human Genome. It's a sound course to take and one that is probably indispensable to any good biology education.
I learned how to effectively solve genetics problems and the genetics behind many developmental diseases.
A lot of conceptual knowledge of genetic; vast overview of the subject from historical significance to real-life applications.
I learned a lot of extremely interesting material and how to take multiple choice tests.
I learned to see the different connections between what seemed to be dissimilar topics.

I learned lots of genetic concepts, like dominant and recessive mutations, histones, population genetics, DNA repair mechanisms, and other cool stuff. I developed the ability to read and practice genetics for hours and hours so as to do well on the quizzes. This class takes a lot out of you. I've gained insight into the types of science I want to focus on for graduate/medical research, and have a fondness for lego giraffes.
I learned about genetics. This was an introductory course covering mutations and repair mechanisms, epigenetics, population genetics, and genetic disorders.
I gained insight into how genetics operates at the molecular and population levels.
Deep but comprehensive dive into the world of genetics. Tough but fun!

I gained a deeper understanding of the complexities of genetics, and learned about the mechanisms and factors that can complicate classic Mendelian ratios of inheritance. I also gained insight into the myriad applications of genetic knowledge.
The class provides a good overview of basic concepts and research methods in genetics, including both population topics and molecular topics.
I learned about many broad genetics concepts and developed a solid understanding of them.
lots of genetics

By taking this course, my ability to analyze scientific papers and present them in a small discussion setting has improved. Overall, this is a great class for anyone who even has a remote interest in genetics and the human genome.
I gained an understanding of many areas of genetics that I had never been taught in intro bio sequence.
I gained a more in depth understanding of many topics in genetics covered only briefly in the introduction to biology module.
This is a good introductory genetics class, focusing on topics that I agree are most important for this type of course.
Solving genetics problems and interpreting the results of experiments - important skills as I hope to pursue biomedical research further.

I think better course logistics regarding grading would help ease the pressure on the professors to try and trick people to avoid giving out too many A's. It's MCDB 202 not MCDB 300+, the material is objectively not difficult and overlaps with the intro bio sequence as well as other 200-level courses.. there has to be a better format for the course (a final-style midterm in lieu of quizzes or with a reduction in # of quizzes perhaps?)

The professors were all over the place. Following lecture was like going through a haunted house blindfolded. There was no discussion of expectations or direction of the course, and it could not have been less helpful for student learning and development.

This was a good class, the information was presented well in lecture and the quizzes are a really good way to keep up with the information without being overwhelmed. One way to improve is to perhaps in the special Tuesday make an effort to make sure everyone is involved in the discussion or lower the participation percentage because it is very high for only a small amount of time to talk.

I thought a huge strength was the special tuesday format - I really liked breaking into smaller, seminar-like sections. I also think that bi-weekly quizzes are a much better way to absorb the material than just one or two high-pressure midterms.

Special Tuesdays are a major strength of the course since section is built into the class schedule. The multiple choice quizzes are challenging but do a mostly good job at reflecting the lecture content. Downsides include the final, which is nothing like the quizzes in terms of format, and participation counting for 25% of the grade when it's so subjective and depends on you understanding scientific literature, which is very difficult for some.

Strengths: Biweekly (every other week) quizzes which tested 3 lectures' worth of material kept me up to date; Dellaporta and Gendron are two of the best and most fun and engaging professors I've had at Yale; the topic is SUPER interesting

Weaknesses: Along with the biweekly quizzes comes a biweekly paper on genetics, which is discussed in section; depending on your TA, you'll either totally understand the paper or you won't

Strong adherence to the syllabus was absent for the first half of the course. Some topics listed on the syllabus was not covered, leaving some confusion about how to prepare for quizzes and the final. However, the second half was great and very well organized.

Professor Dellaporta is great but Professor Gendron was exceptional. Professor Gendron's enthusiasm and engagement with the class always made me excited to come to lecture!

I loved this course. Going in, I was intimidated because it was my first upper level MCDB class, but the clear, informative way both Professors Dellaporta and Gendron taught made me feel confident and comfortable with the material. In the first half of the course, one thing that could be improved is the way Professor Dellaporta breaks up his lectures. He was prone to giving out huge packets of slides knowing that there was no way we could cover all of them in one class. But when we inevitably didn't, we rarely picked up where we left off--instead, we usually just started the next lecture, which made it confusing to remember where we left off/what material we were responsible for. In the second half of the course, I wish there hadn't been so much rote memorization, especially in the mutations and repair unit. I don't know if it was is a function of the material itself or of Professor Gendron's style of teaching, but regardless, I wish there were a little more learning and a little less memorization. Special Tuesdays were another major player in my assessment of the course. I loved and appreciated the break from the lecture style, and going through relevant, often recently published papers in a small group setting was a great way to learn. The quizzes that accompanied the Special Tuesdays, however, were a mixed bag. Sometimes they were totally fair, but sometimes the questions were intentionally ambiguous in their wording or obscure in the details they picked up on, which wasn't great for something worth such a large percentage of the grade. The quizzes did, however, keep me very on top of my work in the class, which made studying for the final easier. On the whole, this course was a really great experience and made me excited to be an MCDB major.

One additional note: Genetics is inherently a very heteronormative subject matter. Everything comes down to the egg and the sperm, the genes you inherit from your mother and from your father... but not in all cases. Even if it is difficult to teach these genetic principles without making some assumptions, I wish the fact that inheritance isn't always perfectly XX/XY were at least addressed.

I thought the final was unfair and weird, and not a proper reflection of our grasp of genetics. Overall, though, I absolutely loved the course. The lectures were very interesting, and the organization was wonderful.

I do wish we received feedback about how we were doing in discussion sections.

I think that the team-taught nature of this class was a great strength and allowed the professors to shine in the areas that they knew better. I think the greatest weakness of this class was that there were many typos in the quizzes and final, which made it harder to understand/take/some of the quiz questions had to be thrown out. I thought the quiz format was good because it made studying for the final a lot easier (we'd been quizzed on all of it before).

As for strengths, the course cover the foundations of genetics comprehensively. The 6-quiz scheme is also very helpful and helps students learn without unnecessary overpressure. 

As for weaknesses, some of the slides were very, very brief and a lot of material was covered in some individual lectures. That especially applies to the first part of the course.

I really loved the structure of the course - biweekly quizzes every other Tuesday and a discussion about a paper. It kept me on top of the material but wasn't too stressful or overwhelming. Not too much I think needs improving. My only suggestion would be that in addition to the optional book problem sets which are helpful, it would be great if the professors would write one or two questions of their own about the topics they stress as very important as practice for the final (i.e chi squared analyses, etc). Also it would be great if we could get the quizzes back sooner.

-strengths: module format, cool papers, quizzes to check in on material

-weaknesses: final exam questions based solely on memorization of unimportant names, cheap in comparison to what we learned, and how things work/create mutagens. GWAS paper

A good lecturer in Dellaporta and a fantastic lecturer in Gendron. 7 biweekly quizzes, drop your lowest to make up 50% of your grade. 25% discussion section and 25% final exam. Studying for quizzes is intense, but it's all multiple choice and people usually do well overall. Not sure about the curve.
The quizzes were sometimes unusually difficult and varied greatly in the amount of detail that we were required to know. We never got our quizzes back so it was difficult to know what we didn't know.

Strengths: comprehensive, exams were fair, learned a lot of material, was very well organized in the second half with Gendron. 

Weaknesses: I didn't feel like the course was well organized when Dellaporta taught it. I never knew what to study and it always seemed like an amalgam of material. That being said, he explained the concepts well and I liked him as a lecturer, I just wish that he were more organized.
Dellaporta needs to follow the textbook more.

This course is taught in two parts by Prof. Dellaporta followed by Prof. Gendron. Each of the topics covered by Dellaporta is very important and exactly what you would expect from a course in genetics. Gendron's lectures are very good as well (mutations as the source of all genetic diversity and developmental biology from the genetic code). Assessments are through what are called "Special Tuesdays" that replace lecture and are held in discussion sections during the class time, comprising a 30 minute quiz followed by a reading of a paper selected by the instructor. I think most students would agree that this format is excellent for keeping up with the material. Importantly however, it should not escape anyone taking the course that 50% of your final course grade is made up from these quizzes and since there are only 6 of them with 10 questions each with the lowest dropped (plus a shorter quiz on the last lecture), the math works out to about 1 point of your final grade per quiz question. The questions on the quizzes are all multiple choice and created so that the mean is expected to be around 7/10. Just something to keep in mind when preparing for the quizzes, which may suit you very well or not.
The paper and discussion sections were very interesting!

I like how the lecture slides were printed out for us at every class. Really great to have a physical copy of the material as well as my notes on the same document. Felt like the material that was covered in class was pretty simple but the questions on the quizzes and exam were definitely much higher level, without much help in between. Yes, the psets were helpful but a lot of that was left to the TFs to unpack/review. Felt like there should be more covered in lecture if that's the main way that we will be evaluated.

I loved the Special Tuesday format of this course! I really felt that it facilitated student learning in a novel way, and found myself more engaged in the course than I might have been otherwise as a result.
The biweekly quizzes were very challenging but the content was extremely interesting. Prof Dellaporta also didnt have time to finish his lectures and I wish he had.

I think the biweekly quizzes are good because they force you to really dive into the topics in each unit and really focus on them. However, I think the class did very little preparation for the final. The quizzes were multiple choice while the final was written answer. Along that note, there were no problem set (they were assigned form the book but never actually graded) so it was very hard to prepare for the types of questions we actually saw on the final. The consequence of this was that the quizzes made up most of, and in my opinion, too much of the grade in the class.

Strengths include easy to understand lectures. An area of improvement would be in the discussion sections as it would have been better if students were able to collaborate with each other in it as opposed to simple ask and answer dialogue with the TA.

Strengths: quizzes every other week to keep you on your toes. Relevant scientific papers to discuss during discussion section (which replaces a class period). TAs are super helpful, and professors usually respond to emails within 24 hours. Fun class! You may or may not have the chance to play with Legos.

Weaknesses: Quizzes are Multiple Choice (not a weakness) but the final is word problems, so the way we tested in the class the entire semester was completely different for the final. There are "optional" word problems for problem sets throughout the course, but these are only really relevant for the final exam. It's weird to have this discord between one form of testing and another.

The format of the course where we have biweekly quizzes are a good way to keep students caught up with the material. I did not enjoy discussion sections over science papers because as a participation grade students were only engaged in class because they were forced to. These lacked genuine participation and were often dull.

I thought the course covered a good amount of material, and I liked that we were given the chance to read interesting papers that allowed us to see how the course material was applied in research. I sometimes felt that we got hung up on certain parts of lectures, which slowed our progression through the material, so if I had to change an aspect of the course, I would have liked to see us move through the lectures at a more appropriate pace.
Quizzes and discussion section format was great - forced you to keep up with the material (in a good way) so you weren't cramming like crazy for the final.
I don't know if the grades were calculated correctly

The course format (quizzes on content blocks in section every 2 weeks, with primary research articles also discussed during section) was strong. One weakness was that the final exam consisted of quantitative questions, which were not heavily covered/practiced throughout the semester.

Good class. Both professors were good lecturers, the papers were interesting and helped clarify the topics that were covered, and the discussion sections were well run. I wish Prof. Dellaporta had been somewhat less ambitious about the topics he intended to cover in each class period, since he often ran out of time. Otherwise, the class was well taught.
The course was well organized to facilitate learning, yet some of the lecture slides could have been more descriptive so that students could review material outside of class.
I really liked the content and the professors, not sure what could've been improved.

Strengths: The special tuesdays where we took quizzes and then followed up with a scientific paper discussion was a great way to review the material. Additionally, the slides were decently straightforward and it was easy enough to follow up with material from the textbook.

Weakness: Sometimes the biweekly papers strayed from the content, making them difficult to understand.
Mandatory problem sets would have benefitted everyone. The quizzes could have been more similar to the final.
I feel like the multiple choice quizzes did not quite prepare me for the written final, although the final itself I thought to be fair.

Strengths - instructor and TFs very helpful and willing to clarify information. Review sessions clearly presented. Slides well organized especially for the lectures taught by Dr. Gendron. Dr. Dellaporta was always approachable and cared about students being engaged and interested. Special Tuesdays format very helpful, preferable to having separate sections. Reading manageable.

Weaknesses/improvements - need to review quizzes during lectures following Special Tuesdays. I can understand concerns with returning the quizzes but I think time should be made to go over the answers and take a few questions for about 15 min. This was done once but I believe it should have happened after each quiz.

Take it but be aware that like other intermediate MCDB courses, there are very active attempts to widen the grade distribution in the class. The material itself is not difficult, but you need to do well on the quizzes (which are worded especially trickily if you have a smart group in your lecture as we did this year) to do well. 11 Multiple choice, graded out of 10. 

I think better course logistics regarding grading would help ease the pressure on the professors to try and trick people to avoid giving out too many A's. It's MCDB 202 not MCDB 300+, the material is objectively not difficult and overlaps with the intro bio sequence as well as other 200-level courses.. there has to be a better format for the course (a final-style midterm in lieu of quizzes or with a reduction in # of quizzes perhaps?)

Unpopular opinion: I enjoyed Professor Dellaporta's lectures more than those with Gendron. The latter part of the course felt like I was on Ellen or something with prizes and candy being thrown across the lecture hall.. and being asked to clap.. this compounded with mumbled reading off a powerpoint followed by a clear "if you were paying attention you'll get that right on the quiz!" is no fun.

That being said, both professors are always open to questions so be sure to ask if you need clarification for anything. Worthwhile course if you're looking for something in MCDB to take.
No. Even if you need it for a major requirement. Switch majors.

The first half of the class is excellent. Prof. Dellaporta is one of the most engaging bio professors I have ever had at Yale. The second half, on the other hand, is rather dry and disconnected, covering a lot of information that's already covered in 103 and random names of molecules to memorize.

This is a good MCDB class to take. It is interesting, I liked to learn the material and the lecture did not drag compared to other classes. There are biweekly quizzes throughout the semester which is very helpful to keep up with the material and then know it all for the final. No information was too confusing to understanding and it was taught clearly.
As a general biology class, yes. It was interesting and challenging but not too difficult.

I'd recommend if you're really interested in genetics as the content is interesting if that's the case. Otherwise, this course caused me a lot of stress and distress and I'm hesitant to recommend unless you need it for a requirement.

Best MCDB class I've taken so far, and I owe it to Dellaporta and Gendron. They made lecture enjoyable and engaging, both because of their clear passion for the subject, and also because Dellaporta has a cool accent and Gendron is straight up hilarious. In terms of the actual material, if you're interested in learning about the basis of the inheritance of human diseases, take the course!

If you are a premed, it's a nice course to take. Although not essential for MCAT, it can be a good supplement. But be prepared for a hoard of try-hard sophomores/juniors who might destroy the curve. Material itself is not too interesting but you will realize its importance in current biological sciences/medicine.

Yes! Take this course! Especially if you're an MCDB major because you do need a baseline level of interest and understanding in the hard science. But still, Professors Dellaporta and Gendron make learning hard material easy, and you will come out of the course will such a better understanding of genes, which literally explain everything. Wow.

This class was great! The lectures were interesting and understandable, and very engaging! The final was tough but the weekly quizzes were very doable. I highly recommend that MCDB majors take this! I feel like I learned so much.
I would recommend this class to another student. I really liked the material, and the workload wasn't too challenging. The professors are engaging and you'll really like what you're learning.
Genetics is a great course! I would definitely recommend it for MCDB majors who are looking for something that's interesting, but not too much work or overly complicated.
Yes

Definitely take this course! If you're at all interested in genetics or interested in anything biology, I'd recommend. The course is really well structured. It's really interesting but also a pretty light course load, unlike many other MCDB courses.
Good class, similar material but more in depth, and organized if you have already taken micro (genetics topics). Great, lots of memorization though, even when it is not explicitly said.

YES! Take it as MCDB core if you're going that route for sure. 

A good lecturer in Dellaporta and a fantastic lecturer in Gendron. 7 biweekly quizzes, drop your lowest to make up 50% of your grade. 25% discussion section and 25% final exam. Studying for quizzes is intense, but it's all multiple choice and people usually do well overall. Not sure about the curve.

Yep! If you're majoring in MCDB, this isn't too hard of a class. Average is a B+/A-, but if you want an A, then stay away from this class unless you're prepared to be the highest in the class. But overall, good class, learned lots of stuff, solid amount of work required, biweekly quizzes and an exam at the end, not too bad.
Genetics is a great way to fulfill the core class requirement for MCDB majors. It is very manageable, the material isn't too challenging, and the tests are fair. Don't blow off the quizzes.
If you are an MCDB major and need a core course - and have already taken cell bio / biochem - I would either choose physiological systems or genetics. Both are helpful in life.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student if he is interested in obtaining a broad view of genetics!

I would absolutely recommend taking Genetics! I didn't need the course for any particular requirement, but decided to take it for fun and it was lots of fun!  You'll learn a lot, and the format is very manageable if you keep on top of the material for each module.  The homework is worth doing, and will help you learn the material for the final exam.  Dellaporta and Gendron are both great instructors, and the class is great overall.  Take this class if you have any interest in Genetics, Evolution, Biology, or just want to learn a bunch of cool stuff in a non-stressful environment.
Yes I would! It's a bit of a challenge but not as stressful as other MCDB core courses are.
Yes I would. All things considered, its not too bad and better than some of the other MCDB electives.

Take this class if you are an MCDB major, or need to take genetics as a requirement for grad/med school. This class is a lot of work, and a lot of questions on tests are worded strangely so pay attention and really think about what the question is asking. This course is better than most 200+ MCDB courses offered, so I recommend it.
I would not recommend this course

I guess I'd recommend the class to another student. The change from multiple choice questions for the quizzes to short response for the final can be a bit jarring, but the course is interesting and the professors were pretty nice. The papers for discussion section were pretty dry, however.

I would take this course if you're interested in learning more about key topics in genetics, especially if you intend on pursuing a career in biology or medicine. The course was a relatively relaxed course compared to other MCDB electives I've taken, and the quizzes are pretty low-stress if you have a good understanding of the material. I wouldn't take this course if you've already taken a good deal of MCDB electives or classes that feature a lot of genetics material, as you might not learn many new concepts.
Yes - tough but super interesting and fun if you (1) enjoy genetics and (2) put the work in.

This course isn't life-changing, but if you are interested in the principles of genetics and how they can be applied to problems in the world (such as disease and the food supply), you will enjoy it and deepen your understanding of science.

Yes. The topics are interesting and are presented in a way that's at least somewhat challenging for someone who has an intermediate knowledge of biology but that isn't unmanageable. The class isn't the most well organized class in Yale College, but overall has a good quality of teaching. The discussion papers are consistently engaging, the discussion sections are very well run, and the subject matter itself is often enjoyable.
Yes! It is an interesting course and definitely worth the work.
Yes, its a great intro genetics course that opens your mind to analyzing things you see all the time (diseases, differences in traits, etc.).

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Both of the professors are passionate about the course material and the TAs are always willing to help. Even though I already had an interest in genetics before this course, I think the class provides a great background for any natural science major.

Absolutely wonderful course. Dellaporta and Gendron are both great professors who care about their students very much. The workload isn't too bad (a quiz every other week and a final). I learned a lot about genetics and I would recommend this course.
Definitely worth it for any MCDB major!
I would recommend Genetics to any science-minded students with a keen interest in topics in genetics.
Yes, it is a wonderful and very thorough introduction to genetics! I loved it!
Yes, it is a comprehensive introduction to topics in genetics and will give you important problem-solving skills for work in biology/biomedical research.
